title: Ausmultiplikation
text:
Ausmultiplikation (literally, "multiplying-out") is a German term used by the composer <a href="Karlheinz%20Stockhausen">Karlheinz Stockhausen</a> to describe a <a href="musical%20technique">technique</a> in which a <a href="duration%20%28music%29">long</a> <a href="Musical%20note">note</a> is replaced by shorter "<a href="melody">melodic</a> configurations, internally animated around central tones", resembling the <a href="ornament%20%28music%29">ornamental</a> technique of <a href="division%20%28music%29">divisions</a> (also called "<a href="diminution">diminution</a>s") in <a href="Renaissance%20music">Renaissance music</a>. Stockhausen first described this technique in connection with his "opus 1", "<a href="Kontra-Punkte">Kontra-Punkte</a>", composed in 1952–53, but in his later <a href="formula%20composition">formula composition</a> there is a related method of substituting a complete or partial formula for a single very long tone in a much slower, "more <a href="musical%20form">background</a>" projection of the formula. When this is done at more than one level, the result is reminiscent of a <a href="fractal">fractal</a>.
Notes and references.
